title: Tax HiveMind Window
text:
This HiveMind has closed so it's no longer possible to vote on statements or add statements for others to vote on. You can still explore the opinion groups and majority opinions by clicking on the graphic below.

Email hivemind@scoop.co.nz if you have any queries, complaints or need help.

comments.text: Results of cutting the size of Government. Slower growth than other OECD countries, costly services, poverty, and collapsing infrastructure
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: GST was a simple switch, to make those on low incomes pay more tax, to finance those on high incomes paying less.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A living wage prevents large firms from removing as much wealth, as they do, from communities.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Top tax rates in Australia are over 45%. New Zealand has plenty of room for a tax free bracket on low and higher taxes on high incomes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Wealthy individuals and companies have removed money from tax cuts, from our community, rather than re-investing, as Rogernomics promised.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax is the cost of living in a civilised and functioning society.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Successful countries past and present have Government spending at 50 to 60% of GDP. New Zealand is around 30%.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: WWF is a subsidy for employers, who do not pay fair wages.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The lack of inheritance and capital gains taxes, in New Zealand, makes for an unfair and badly balanced tax system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: sGST is strongly regressive(impacts mainly on lower earners)and should be replaced with wealth and financial transaction taxes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: GST on rates should be set at zero. Either that or the Government pass on to the Councils the GST portion on rates instalments collected.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: my savings approximately $6,400.00 which in the year to March 31 2018 paid gross interest of $6.69 had tax deducted $1.08 net interest $5.31
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax the wealthiest 15% significantly more on their wealth. They have benefited most due to poor government policy at the expense if most.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Drivers licences and changes to the are charged fees (govt income) plus gst (more govt income).  This is an abuse of power over citizens.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: all taxes should be structured to reduce inequality gradually over a decade or two by including wealth in their assessment
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: All income should be taxed on the same basis, whether from wages, salary, self-employment or capital gain.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should be a tax-free threshold of $20K. It's an incentive to  work, and cuts the bureaucracy of taxing then giving back in benefits
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am prepared to pay a higher tax rate to improve our public services
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Installing solar panels and storage batteries on all state house is an imperative.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Free dental/medical care funded for beneficiaries relying  solely on their benefit for income. Poor  health costs taxpayers dearly.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: No tax exemption for charities.  Services now done by charities eg Refuge would be funded by the tax, & Sanitarium etc would pay fair tax.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: People, the environment, the culture, health and happiness of people is more important than purchase power or corporate interests.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Local government / councils should be forced to amalgamate to reduce duplication between small councils and thus reduce rates.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax rate thresholds should be adjustment by inflation each year (as per the UK) to ensure the proportion of tax paid remains the same
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Company income tax is only 16% of the total tax take. Changes should be made to increase this, particularly from multi-national companies
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I'm gay
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Working for families creates middle class beneficiaries and perverse incentives to turn down promotions that would lead to long term gain
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A wealth tax on savings from already taxed income is unfair and unreasonably punishes / discourages positive economic behaviour
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Many of the statements are cannot be answered by simply agree or disagree
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax structures should not exaggerate and amplify inequality
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The community pays tax to provide the services everyone needs - from each according to their means, to each according to their needs.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The tax people pay must fairly reflect the total personal wealth benefits they have - not just the "income" they declare to IRD.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Nothing
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ariana
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Cut all taxes except GST.  Don't allow offsets for business. Thisbperhaps would be fairest tax for all.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ should reduce tax on income and increase it on wealth and pollution.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: implement a Tobin Tax to discourage short term currency speculation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobin_tax
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Create a directory of foreign owned trusts to prevent the $1.35bn of money laundered in NZ each year http://bit.ly/transparencyNZ
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: in 2013 107 out of 161 high-wealth individuals, declared less $70,000 income. Find people like this & tax them. http://bit.ly/taxavoiders12
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The government should work much harder to reel in the estimated $2bn of tax fraud each year. http://bit.ly/taxfraud2014
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A very small (1%) tax for every financial transaction (transfer, withdrawal etc) would be fair
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Spending Power in New Zealand is too centralised.  Give local authorities more ability to improve the lives of their communities.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Taxes need to be simple to understand and transparent
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Taxes are useful to influence behaviour as well as raising revenue
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I see cheap food in UK, Aus & USA. Gst penalises children & low wage. Food/water/home shouldnt be a luxury item for elites
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A gradual pollution tax for business to provide funds for cleaning up and to discourage pollution. The more pollution the higher the tax.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Lifting benefit abatement rates would encourage beneficiaries to transition to work and help lift them above the poverty line.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tobacco extortion tax is eroding NZ society in a wide range of area's and contributing to that which inhibits reason.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Capital gains tax should be treated differently for housing, investments or business assets
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Small businesses hiring beneficiaries should be incentivised through tax
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Capital gains tax, if implemented, should only be incurred at the point of sale of property
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: People without children who are on low incomes should get rebates or income top ups similar to working for families
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Secondary tax rates should be adjusted to reflect total income
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: When the minimum wage rises, all benefits that are calculated in line with earnings or limits and clawbacks should also be adjusted
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Beneficiaries who earn income should have a lesser clawback of their benefits to encourage them to maximise their work opportunities
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Helping communities take responsibility for their issues should mean more funding from taxes being controlled locally instead of centrally.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's clear and concise
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The GST should be removed from basic foods. It is a regressive tax that hits the poor hardest.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ Statistics show that after tax and transfers, NZ inequality has not been growing in the last 20 years, unlike other places in the world.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Consideration of the "fairness" of tax needs to include the full tax and transfer system - that is why we have benefits and WFF.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Australia has a capital gains tax, and very high property prices.  A capital gains tax is unlikely to materially impact property prices.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Effective marginal tax rates (EMTR) matter.  The highest EMTRs are for those moving off a benefit.  A tax free threshold would help them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Those with more should pay more in tax.  Those with more means those with wealth, not necessarily income - we should consider a wealth tax
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax evasion by any means should be seen as a crime against the society.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I envision that a flat tax across the board with no exemptions or loop holes on all earnings from any source (say 20%) and a GST
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It is not a lack of tax income that leads to underfunded services, but rather the choices made by government on what are priorities to fund
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Clear and concise
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We should be following countries like Australia and the UK and ensuring multinationals pay their fair share of tax in New Zealand where people are using their services.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Whereas workers pay income tax, the robots / machines that replace them do not. May be there should be a production tax, a VAT on value created
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: All taxes should be structured so the more you earn the more you pay. No tax should be regressive like GST.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Legal tax avoidance by multinationals must be addressed as a matter of priority. This revenue could ensure wealth was paying its fair share.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Churches must pay tax. Companies like Sanitarium have utilised church exemptions  undermining other businesses and creating inequity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Loopholes which allow the wealthy to pass far less tax percentage wise must be closed to ensure a fair and equitable tax system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Reduce income tax to 10% flat and increase GST, taxing on consumption is fairer and also taxes under the table and black market economy.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Tax system should not be used as an excuse to underfund vital public services
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In a fiat money system like ours the government can always 'fund' its programs, no matter how much or little the government taxes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Taxes should be used to prevent inflation and inequality
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: GST disproportionately affects poor people and inflates prices. It should be removed
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The tax system should be rebalanced - lower incomes' taxes should be reduced, and taxes on the wealthy increased
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Since the 1980s the tax system has been used to benefit wealthy interests at the expense of working people
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Taxes do not fund government spending
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our tax system should ensure wealth does not become concentrated and warp our society
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 'Sin taxes' (such as taxes on cigarettes or alcohol) don't significantly change behaviour and mainly punish poor people
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: the tax working group should have included a random selection ordinary citizens not just politicians and experts
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Whereas workers pay income tax, the robots / machines that replace them do not. Should there be a production Tax,  a VAT on value created?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We should tax that which causes harm or is otherwise unsustainable for the environment e.g. pollution, use of fossil fuels etc
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Reducing waste could generate as much money as increasing taxes - our government is top heavy and over-peopled, let's slim it down.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: You can't lump pollution and sugar togeher but I agree with portions of this argument.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Clear & concise
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A UBI and government spending, funded by government created money, could be used to fund the economy. Taxes would then control inflation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Government spending used to fund the economy. Taxes would then be a control mechanism for the amount of money in the system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our monetary system needs to be changed to a Sovereign Monetary system. Govt would then fund the economy & taxes controlling inflation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I propose Increasing GST to 25-30% and ban all Income Tax and dissolve the IRD as I would become a redundant department
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax is an issue for all of us. The Tax Working Group written submission process is not sufficiently democratic and they should have designed a comprehensive public engagement process
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Lower personal PAYE Flat Tax for all income earners. Higher rates for different persons is inequitable & encourages avoidance & dishonesty.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Companies should not have loopholes, designed to avoid tax,  get exemptions or rebates. Flat tax 20% completely overall.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: FLAT TAX SYSTEM 20% If you earn a $1000 a week you are Flat Tax is fairest equitable way. Tax laws 4 companies give too many rebates exempt
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need more eco-based taxes to encourage better ecologically beneficial behaviours.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to introduce a universal basic income for all residents.  Our UBI, NZSuper, works well - make it for all, starting with children.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Too much of our tax take is derived from income and consumption. Owners of capital need to bear a far bigger share than they currently do.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A tax on wealth (supported by a gift tax) is a fair and reasonable way to tax accumulated wealth.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: People who fall on hard times should have access to basic services in a timely manner. These should be funded by national taxes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our top tax bracket is 33% from $70,001. Our median income is only a bit more than $20,000 less than that. We need another tax bracket.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our income tax is some of the lowest in the OECD and this has lead to under-funding of services needed by low income families.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tourism burdens NZ’s environment & essential infrastructure (roads, sewerage, water, health etc.) Impose an entry tax for all non citizens.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A land or property tax based on the average increase in property value billed with rates is a far better idea than a capital gains tax.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to encourage start-ups and self-employment by cutting taxes on new small businesses, increasing them to normal gradually over time.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax isn’t a weapon politicians use against the economy. It’s what we use to pool our resources and secure the things we need: schools, hospitals, homes and more.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Good quality, accessible public services are the necessary foundations for any well-functioning nation
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ’s current tax settings have contributed to growing income, wealth and social inequalities.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ’s current tax settings have encouraged property speculation, which has contributed to making housing unaffordable for many New Zealanders.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ should re-institute wealth taxes (e.g. death and gift duties) to make the tax system fairer and more progressive.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Apart from Working For Families, changes to the tax system have tended to unfairly favour wealthy people at the expense of low and middle income earners.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A broader tax base is needed to secure sufficient revenue for public services in the face challenges such as climate change, an aging population, changing employment patterns and new technologies.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A Tobin tax on financial transactions should be introduced to discourage international speculation, which can wreak havoc with NZ’s exchange rate and economy.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The total tax take needs to increase as public services such as health and education have been underfunded for years.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Business innovation and new technologies mean that workers will be out of work more often and need to retrain. This will reduce revenue from income tax. New ways of supporting these workers will need to be found (e.g. a universal basic income) and paid for.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Local government is already under pressure to deliver many essential services, including local roading, water supplies and flood protection. These pressures are likely to increase with climate change. We're rated enough. Funding for local government needs to be sorted urgently.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The most glaring hole in New Zealand’s tax system, from a fairness point of view, is the failure to tax wealth in any form, except for the government’s very minimal tax on houses sold within two years of purchase.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Home ownership can boost local communities and social stability. But fewer people live in their own homes, which are increasingly unaffordable. Fixing that is a complex issue…but taxes on wealth are among the policies that need to change.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tax exemptions for low income households should be increased to help overcome inequalities
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Excise tax on cigarettes have helped reduce smoking. Similar taxes should be considered for other issues such as pollution, traffic congestion and sugar consumption.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The GST rate should be reduced as GST is a regressive tax that impacts low income families most.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Digital technologies should make it possible to efficiently collect taxes even if there are lots of different rates and exemptions.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Taxes should not be used to change behaviours - consumers should be left to decide what is best for them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should be no exemptions to GST as it’s impossible to rationally decide what should and should not be exempt. Exemptions are gamed by companies and are only good for the lawyers.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We are taxed more than what can be justified. Individuals, families and businesses are best placed to decide how to spend or invest their money
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We should lower taxes because this would help improve the economy by boosting spending
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Lowering taxes would help create the right incentives for people to invest and work hard. This will improve productivity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Government is inefficient and lower taxes would mean more efficient spending by the private sector
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Low taxes are the only real check on the size of government
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A broad-based, low-rate system with few exemptions is the best overall approach to tax in New Zealand
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: To enable NZ companies to compete internationally, the company tax rate needs to be reduced so that it is similar to those in countries we trade with.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My household income is above  $150,000 per year
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My household income is above  $100,000 per year but less than or equal to $150,000 per year
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My household income is above $50,000 per year but less than or equal to $100,000 per year
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My household’s income is $50,000 per year or less
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am unemployed
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am self-employed
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I own a business
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I own property
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My highest qualification is from secondary school
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in a rural area
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in a town or small city
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in a major city
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am 55 years old or older
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am between 30 and 55 years old
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am either 30 years old or younger
comments.author: Anonymous
